nodes.bodyText:
how often is it <= 4096? If this happens often, we should skip cache logic for this
like
if (<= 4096)  f1 = minvalue
else if (incache)
so that the cache isn't getting clobbered by static values
It should only be <= 4096 when generating the main end island and the surrounding ~1000 blocks of void 😅

This should probably be stored per-generator-instance. Even then there’s still a concern of handling threaded generation since this cache does not work concurrently- is it possible for concurrent generation of chunks on the same generator instance with Paper?
Might be beneficial to avoid the double map-lookup by storing a separate object that contains the keys and values?
This probably shouldn't need to use a linked map. Possibly even can use a Reference2ObjectMap, which can give better performance if reference equality is valid here?

+Date: Tue, 3 Nov 2020 23:48:05 -0600
+Subject: [PATCH] Significantly improve performance of the end generation
+
+This patch implements a noise cache for the end which significantly reduces the computation time of generation. This results in about a 3x improvement.

nodes.bodyText:
Not really sure that a ThreadLocal is the best idea, especially if you have worlds loading/unloading, any reason why this is preferred over just using a standard map/array?
There's no real garauntees over how threads will be handled, e.g. if we get parallel, will it be using multiple threads which are killed afterwards, etc
Could just store it in a singular array per manager, that way you can "guarantee" enough safety there

If we have an instance of WorldChunkManagerTheEnd per world, that should unload memory as a world unloads.
Though thread safety SHOULD be provided by the world gen system under CURRENT design as a single world is only being generated by a single thread at a time.
The only case I can see this mattering is if this noise cache is shared across multiple worlds.

Our code used ThreadLocal as the backing lossy cache isn't thread safe. Even though the generation isn't done concurrently, we wanted to be extra sure we wouldn't mess anything up. While it's not the best solution, it gets the job done 😅

It doesn't hurt to be future proof. I was more responding to Cats concern over world loading.
As long as my understanding is correct that we have an instance per world and its not shared between worlds, there should be no concerns over memory leak and I think this current impl is good to go.
Yea, I didn't realize that the locals where stored on the Thread, so should be cleaned up when the thread is dead, so that's a non-issue, at this point, lgtm

I do think ThreadLocal is the best choice here to be as absolutely safe as possible while remaining performant.
I was able to confirm after doing heap analysis that a memory leak does exist when unloading and loading an end dimension as the worker threads never die. I was able to easily resolve this issue by swapping the Reference2ObjectMap with a WeakHashMap so that the GC will cleanup no longer in use noise generator keys. Thankfully, it remains just as performant as the original PR description results.
